SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you'd rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name ... Mrs. Sarah Reaville .......................
2. Your address ... Racamville ..................................
3. Date .... May 2nd ... 1952 ......
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) Township Medora, County Simcoe, Ontario, Canada
5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   John Kinghorn, farmer & carpenter
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
   April 1883
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc).
   17 years

9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   My sister and her husband were out here, and we came to make a home here

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?).
    We learned through my sister's family.
1. Your full name: Mrs. Sarah Reavis

2. Your address: Brandonville

3. Date: May 8th

4. Where were you born? County of Simcoe, Ontario, Canada

5. What was your father's name? John Kingham, farmer and carpenter

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? April 1888

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child.")

9. What were your reasons for coming West? My sister and her husband went out there, and we came to make a home here.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railhead or government information?) We learned through my sister's family.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   My father and mother and sister & brother and myself.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   We came by train to Moosomin and we had our implements & our cattle and we had to freight by horses the 20 mile to Rocanville district.

14. What incidents of the journey west do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)
   It was very quiet.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   We stayed at Moosomin overnight and hitched up next day to come out.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   We took up land six miles West of Rocanville.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
   None.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?
   I worked out a little and my mother went out nursing.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

My father and mother and sister & brother

13. What means of transportation did you use?

We came by train to Moosemin and we had our compliments & our cattle and we had to freight by horse the 20 mile to Rosterville district.

14. First incidents of the journey (lost do you remember? People you met on the way; meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, etc.).

It was very quiet

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

We stayed at Moosemin overnight and hitched up next day to come out and took up land

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Six miles west of Rosterville

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

None

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

I worked out a little and my mother went out nursing.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

I wrote quite often to an aunt, my father's sister in Ontario.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

My husband's name was Colin Reavie. We were married on our farm.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

Into a few people.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

We came together except for my older sister.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

I can remember my young man had go to fight to put down the Riel rebellion and he came back safely. The pigs were scraping around the fence and knocked out our yeast off and I had to walk 4 miles to get yeast. I remember the first meal in our new home when we got out of the tent - we had new potatoes and butter and mother's good bread.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

We attended everything that went on. We travelled by team and buggy. We used to go at least 7 miles to church. We used to sometimes walk there.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

My husband's name was Colin Reavie. We were married on our farm.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation it as a place to settle? Just a few people.

We came together except for my older sister.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

I can remember my young man had to fight to put down the Riot Rebellion and he came back safely.

The pigs were escaping around the fence and knocked out our yeast off and I had to walk 4 miles to get yeast. I remember the first meal in our new home when we got out of the tent - we had new potatoes and butter and mother's good bread.

We attended everything that went on.

We traveled by team and buggy. We used to go at least 7 miles to church. We used to sometimes walk there.
25. When was the first car used in the community?
   A delivery car.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?
   About 1912, a Ford.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   Mosomin, 28 miles.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   We traded there for some time after Rockville town began.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   We shopped once a week.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   About the time the cars began.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   I haven't started yet.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   About 1910.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   Yes, we brought everything with us at first.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

They all stayed.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

We had good back bone, and we stayed with what we had.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

My husband's brother Jack Reavie was a member of the first Orange lodge in our district and helped build it. We owned the first automobile in our neighborhood.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (2); (2), (3).

Our local post office was named Rocanville after Mr Henry Rocan Bastien who drove the mail from Moosomin to Redpath those days. Mr. Bastien had partly studied for a doctor and taught his wife a half-breed so she went out nursing. Mr. Bastien originally worked for the Hudson Bay company and was a Frenchman.
They all stayed.

My husband's brother Jack Reavil (Reavil) was a member of the first Orange Lodge in our district and helped build it.

We owned the first automobile in our neighborhood.

Our local post office was named Reaville after Mr Henry Reavil who drove the mail from Miramichi to Redpath three days. The Reavil had partly studied for a doctor and taught his wife a half-breed, so she went out nursing. Mr. Reavil originally worked for the Hudson Bay company and was a gunsmith.
Our district or neighborhood belongs to the first Homemakers club in Rock. Mrs. Sherman Harrison is secretary. Roanville Club. We have a number of old members today but keep them.

(1) We would lend them to the Historical Association for anything.
(2) We would lend them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Raleigh, or the Archives Office at the University in Greensboro.

If someone else has filled in this questionnaire for you, please have this person give name and address here:

Mrs. Annie Loomby Wilson
Roanville, N.C.

My experience on the Homestead

One experience I remember distinctly was when my youngest son, aged 2 1/2 years fell into a 14 foot well and the only circle was in the centre. He dropped the pail and rope in and I had nothing but the box on top of the well to hold on to. I held on with my two hands and kicked but I could not find that circle. Then I let go of one hand, my toe touched the circle and I had courage enough to let go with both hands and I felt I was getting from somewhere and I landed on that circle and turned my face around with my face to the water where my baby was floating. The water was up to my knees as the circle was below water. I held him with his little head down and worked his arms, calling for help. When help came from the far field, I handed up my baby which went in a little lump pile on the grass, then my husband lifted me at 3 P.M and it was 6 P.M when he breathed. He went to the war in 1914-1918. Came home safely and married Miss Constance Dryden Legore, men with me and raised 4 fine teacher Allan that was boarding with me and raised 4 fine boys. They are all farming here in the Roconville District. Their names are as follows at this date May 3/52.

(Jack) John Reavie
Wilford Colin Reavie
Donald Reavie
Brian Reavie
